title: Interplay Between Diet, Stress, and the Gut Microbiome on Health Outcomes
abstract: In this comprehensive study, we delve into the complex interplay between dietary habits, gut microbiome diversity, stress levels, and their cumulative effects on cardiovascular health and obesity. Utilizing a longitudinal dataset from a cohort of over 10,000 participants, our analysis reveals significant causal and correlational relationships. We found that a high intake of processed foods causes an increase in obesity rates, while a diverse gut microbiome inhibits the negative effects of stress on cardiovascular health. Furthermore, our results indicate a positive correlation between gut microbiome diversity and robust cardiovascular health, alongside a negative correlation between chronic stress and gut microbiome diversity. These findings underscore the intricate connections that dietary habits, the gut microbiome, and stress levels share with obesity and cardiovascular health, offering new avenues for preventive strategies and therapeutic interventions.
